DOC.HEAD: Amoco Refinery Blast Kills One Worker, Injures Another
Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 4th graf, `Kurt Sides ...,' to UPDATE with quotes from Miller, more details; picks up 5th graf, `Miller said ...'
DOC.TEXT: Leaking butane gas exploded Saturday at an Amoco Oil Co. refinery, killing one worker and injuring another, a company spokesman said. Amoco and Casper firefighters took three hours to put out the blaze, which began with a flash of fire around 6:30 a.m. Rick Nemitz, 33, was killed when the gas ignited as he was shutting down an outdoor refinery unit, and was either blown to the ground or fell from an upper deck, according to spokesman D. Allen Miller. Kurt Sides, 31, who had been working on the ground, suffered second- and third-degree burns to his face and left hand, Miller said. Sides was in stable condition at Wyoming Medical Center. ``We don't have any idea what ignited the butane,'' Miller said. ``At this point we don't even know the extent of the damage.'' No one else was in the area at the time of the blast, Miller said. The unit, which combines butane and other gases to produce high-octane gasoline, will be shut down until investigators can determine the cause of the blaze. The leak occurred at the connection point of two pipes, Miller said. Miller said there must have been a very high concentration of butane before the blast because such gas leaks usually dissipate into the air. He said he didn't know what ignited the gas. Amoco officials and the federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration were investigating the accident, the spokesman said. Amoco Oil is a subsidiary of Amoco Corp.
